comment: Remember to play with a plan! The last few moves are setting up a nice attack but do you understand what you are trying? Often we hear the mantra to develop, so we develop and miss the point behind why we are making the move. The idea of the opening is to create an "imbalance" [any difference in the position] - especially in minor piece position - and develop around it. One idea of developing the Bishop to f4 is to play h3 to give the Bishop a safe haven while keeping the Knight at bay. BTW the pawns at e4 and c4 are considered a strong strategy against the Sicilian.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake by highlighting the importance of following a plan and understanding the underlying purpose behind each move, such as creating an imbalance and using development to prepare for an attack.

The pawns at e4 and c4 are strong, but simply developing the Bishop to f4 without a clear plan can leave the position overly passive and less dynamic.

comment: I find in my lost games that I generally had a "big miss." Well, this one is yours. After 17. exd6 the game is over, you can hear the "fat lady warming up." The pawn on d6 moves to d7 and completely chokes Black's middle. The Black Rooks become totally useless and you own all the important squares. All this is helped by the useless placement of the Black Queen. Even 17. Ng5 does close to mortal damage to Black threatening both 18. exd6 and 18. Qd5.
reasoning: The comment accurately describes the mistake made by the player, highlighting the loss of control over the board, the weakening of the black rooks, and the threats posed by the white pieces.

reformulated: "White's 17. exd6 move seals the game, as Black's middle is completely blocked by their own pawn. Black's pieces lose their power, especially the Rooks, as they're cornered. The White pieces hold all the crucial squares. Even if Black tried a counter like 17. Ng5, White would still be in a strong position, threatening significant damage with moves like 18. exd6 or 18. Qd5."

comment: Please, do not help your opponent! Remember, never force your opponent to do something you will regret. 19. Qc1! Attacks the Knight on f4, if that is what you want, and holds the back line down nicely. One thing you must learn is when a threat is real and when it is not. The ideal is to ignore your opponent's threats and execute your own. To do this you must learn to distinguish between the real and the imagined.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake made by the player by highlighting the missed opportunity to attack the opponent's knight and emphasizing the importance of recognizing real threats in chess.

It's important for White to consider the strengths of their pieces and the safety of the king. It's critical to evaluate the real threats on the board and not get distracted by potential but unrealistic threats from Black.

comment: 21. cxd3 was necessary. It is ugly but playable. It's better than what happened. White is saddled with two "backward" pawns - on d3 and on b3. I'd call this a positional nightmare, but against a weak opponent you will have an interesting fight on your hands. The squares in front of them are called "holes" where Black will plant a piece. This is called a "blockade." The strength of a blockade is that the pawn is immobile. In chess, if it doesn't [or can't] move it will suffer violence. Keep your position as flexible as possible while coaxing your opponent into making his as ridged as possible. Another strength of the blockade is that it is a base of operation against the opponent. The blockader can not be attacked through the weak pawn.
reasoning: The comment effectively explains the mistake made by the player as it highlights the strategic disadvantages of moving cxd3, particularly focusing on the creation of a blockade which limits the mobility of the pawns and weakens the player's position.
moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 d6 4. O-O Be6 5. d3 Bxc4 6. dxc4 Nf6 7. Re1 g6 8. Bf4 Bg7 9. Nc3 O-O 10. Rb1 Ng4 11. Nd5 Qa5 12. h3 Nf6 13. e5 Nh5 14. Bg5 Qxa2 15. Nxe7+ Nxe7 16. Bxe7 Rfc8 17. b3 dxe5 18. Nxe5 Nf4 19. Re4 Re8 20. Nd3 Nxd3 21. Re2 Nf4
context: This is a game between W15 (as White) and B15 (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Knight to f4
reformulated: 21. cxd3 was necessary, although it's considered unsightly. The move puts Black in a challenging position with two "backward" pawns on d3 and b3. This creates a positional nightmare but may yield interesting play against a weaker opponent. Black's strategy involves creating a "holes" blockade, where a piece is placed in front of the immobile pawns, making it difficult for White to attack. The blockade serves as a strong base of operation for Black, who can't easily target the weak pawns. The key is to maintain flexibility while forcing the opponent into a rigid formation.

comment: 23. Qf3 or 23. Rc1. Your idea of chasing the Knight with the Bishop is misguided and at this point fatal. Don't attack something for the sake of attacking. Always ask yourself, "what is my opponent threatening?" "If I move this what can my opponent threaten or take?" You must have a solid positional reason to attack. Generally if it is mobile, look somewhere else unless you are attempting to create a weakness such as immobility or a poorly defended piece. As much as possible "over protect" everything [pieces and important squares]. By creating an interlocking web of pieces you will make them "all" mobile [perfect for attack or defense]. Think "internet." Anything that "inters" it doesn't leave with all its body parts.
reasoning: The comment effectively explains the mistake as it addresses the player's lack of consideration for their opponent's threats, advises on the importance of having a positional reason for attacking, and provides strategic advice on how to strengthen their position by "over protecting" and creating interconnected pieces.

It's essential for players to consider their opponent's threats and strategic intentions. A well-coordinated group of pieces typically offers better mobility for attack or defense. It's more prudent to strengthen one's position and avoid unnecessary exchanges that lead to weaknesses. By reinforcing key squares and pieces, a player can create a robust structure that's difficult for the opponent to penetrate. Always prioritize safety and structure over immediate tactical gains.

comment: Black misses mate in five [forced]. Cover the screen and figure it out. 30/ \Ng3+ 31. Kg1 Rxe1+ 32. Kh2 Nf1+ 33. Kh1 Ne3+ 34. Kh2 Qxg2#. You should be able to follow this in your mind and see it at the board because they are all forced moves. Track forced moves all the way through. Always consider check. A check is a free move. Following a "line of checks" often leads to checkmate.
reasoning: The comment provides a clear and detailed explanation of the forced checkmate sequence, helping the player understand where they missed the opportunity to win.

context: This is a game between W15 (as White) and B15 (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Pawn to c3
reformulated: Black should have known the game was over with mate in five moves. They need to stay focused on the board. The sequence is: Ng3+ forces White to move, followed by Rxe1+ forcing White to Kh2. Then Nf1+ leads to Kh1, and finally Ne3+ delivers the checkmate with Qxg2#. Always watch out for check. Checks are advantageous because they give you a free move. Following a sequence of checks can lead to checkmate.

comment: O.K. so he got you in four moves, but he needed your help. An idea to prolong the game would have been to move your Q to b1 instead of moving the pawns. I suspect when you start moving pawns you are out of plans. Suggestions for improvement: Keep up the slash and attack style. Be a threat to everyone you meet. Put some effort into learning pawn play. "Pawns are the soul of chess." Most plans revolve around the pawn structure. If you get this down you will become difficult for the "sharks" [2000+ players] to handle. Don't give away pieces! Don't force your opponent to do anything you will regret. Don't panic - if you find yourself tempted to move pawns sit on your hands and breath [that's when you inhale and exhale air from your lungs - I often forget in a tense game] then look for a logical line that the position demands. Keep examining your lost games, your courage will take you far! [I read that on a "Chinese fortune" cookie once - grin.] Develop an attitude: If my opponent can beat me they will have to do it without my help!
reasoning: The comment provides a detailed analysis of the player's mistake and offers constructive advice on how to improve by focusing on pawn play, strategy, and emotional control during the game.

reformulated: O.K., white has fallen four moves prematurely, yet it's crucial to recognize the necessity of white's assistance in this mishap. Instead of advancing pawns, a more strategic move would've been to reposition the queen to b1, thereby enhancing the play. As white, it's essential to maintain a dynamic, slashing attack style, posing threats to all opponents. Improving knowledge in pawn strategy is vital; understanding pawn play is fundamental, as many plans hinge on pawn structures. It's important to avoid unnecessary piece sacrifices and prevent compelling the opponent into detrimental actions. In moments of tension, avoid hasty pawn advances; instead, analyze the position to find the most logical moves. Reflecting on lost games can be enlightening and instrumental in your chess development. Lastly, adopting an attitude that acknowledges when an opponent outmaneuvers you is crucial for growth.
